required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Unfavorable MRI But Favorable 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI for Primary Prostate Cancer Detection
clinical_study.official_title: Diagnostic Performance of 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI in Suspicious Biopsy-naive Prostate Cancer Patients With Favorable Lesion on PET But Unfavorable on MRI for Primary Prostate Cancer Detection: a Pilot Study

lead_sponsor.agency: The Affiliated Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital of Nanjing University Medical School

clinical_study.source: The Affiliated Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital of Nanjing University Medical School

brief_summary.textblock: This perspective cohort study aims to assess the detection rate of prostate cancer through prostate biopsy within suspicious patients harboring unfavorable multiparametric MRI but favorable 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI who have had no prior prostate biopsy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Multiparametric MRI (MpMRI) is currently regarded as the best imaging method to noninvasively identify and characterize prostate cancer (PCa) with the Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System (PI-RADS) v2. However, there are diagnostic difficulties for suspicious patients with PI-RADS score 3 and not all PCa are equivalently visible on mpMRI. For such patients, other alternative imaging techniques are required to properly characterize and detect PCa.
It has been widely reported that 68Ga-PSMA PET imaging offers excellent performance in detecting primary PCa and is able to noninvasively characterize the aggressiveness of PCa. Recently, integrated PET/MRI, which combines the strengths of both modalities, has been shown to have great potential for influencing clinical practice by providing a more certain map of localized PCa to aid targeted biopsies and therapy.
This perspective cohort study aims to assess the detection rate of PCa through prostate biopsy within suspicious patients harboring unfavorable mpMRI but favorable 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI who have had no prior prostate biopsy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Detection rates of clinically significant PCa and clinically insignificant prostate cancer
secondary_outcome.description: Detection rates of clinically significant PCa and clinically insignificant prostate cancer

secondary_outcome.measure: Gleason grade group distribution (score from 1 to 5, the bigger the score, the worse the prognosis) and aggressive architecture (such as cribriform) on final pathology
secondary_outcome.description: Gleason grade group distribution (score from 1 to 5, the bigger the score, the worse the prognosis) and aggressive architecture (such as cribriform) on final pathology

secondary_outcome.measure: Optimal cut-off uptake value on PET/MRI for prostate cancer detection
secondary_outcome.description: Optimal cut-off uptake value on PET/MRI for prostate cancer detection

arm_group.description: Both targeted biopsy and 12-core systematic biopsy with positive 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI

intervention.description: All participants will undergo multiparametric MRI examination. If mpMRI is unfavorable for prostate cancer, participants will undergo 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI examination
Participants with unfavorable mpMRI but favorable 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI will undergo both 68Ga-PSMA PET/MRI-ultrasound-fusion targeted biopsy and transperineal ultrasound guided 12-core systematic biopsy

overall_official.affiliation: The Affiliated Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital of Nanjing University Medical School

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The Affiliated Nanjing Drum Tower Hospital of Nanjing University Medical School
responsible_party.investigator_title: Executive officer of Department of Urology, Drum Tower Hospital, Medical School of Nanjing University, Institute of Urology, Nanjing University
